Description: Limestone plaque bearing a relief representation of Bes. His right arm is upraised, probably once brandishing a sword (noe lost, the left hand grasps a snake. Corners lost; top of head, left foot, and right arm missing. Carved from soft light grey limestone.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Five examples of limestone plaques of Bes are known from Naukratis (1886,0401.1579; 1885,1101.13; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.173; Brussels, Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire E.5019; Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,16). Similar depictions of Bes were discovered in the 'Bes chambers' of Saqqara (Quibell 1907, Pl.xxvi-xxix). Quibell, 1907. Excavations at Saqqara 1905-1906. Le Caire: Imprimerie de l'Institut français d'archéologie orientale.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (CE.181) (Phase 3)
